sen.e: Later, she gave birth to the first princess, Imperial Princess Seishi in 1737 and the second princess, Imperial Princess Toshiko (later Empress Gosakuramachi) in 1740.

sen.e: In 1745, she adopted Imperial Prince Tohito (later Emperor Momozono), a birth child of Sadako ANEGAKOJI, naishi no suke (a court lady of the first rank), because she did not birth to a baby boy.

sen.e: The Emperor Momozono was enthroned at the age of just seven and thus the retired Emperor Sakuramachi ruled the country, but the retired Emperor Sakuramachi demised in 1750, just three years after the enthronement.

sen.j: 天皇の実子である英仁親王（のちの後桃園天皇）は未だ5歳であったことから、摂関家当主らの合議の上、故天皇の異母姉で、舎子の実子である智子内親王が、英仁親王が成長するまでの中継ぎとして即位。
sen.e: As the Emperor's own child, Imperial Prince Hidehito (later Emperor Gomomozono), was just five years old at that time, the heads of the line of regents and advisers (advisors) consulted together and decided that Imperial Princess Toshiko, the late Emperor's half sister and Ieko's own child, was enthroned as an interim emperor until Imperial Prince Hidehito gets older.

sen.e: In 1771, Empress Gosakuramachi abdicated the throne to Imperial Prince Hidehito, thereby Emperor Gomomozono was enthroned, but he also demised at the age of twenty-two in 1779 after his father Emperor Momozono.

sen.e: Since Emperor Gomomozono left only one princess, Imperial Princess Yoshiko, who was just born in the same year, the imperial line of Emperor Nakamikado became extinct.
